title: Shurima / Desert / Sand  Zac
body: {{champion:154}} Zac Needs a new skin or two. Since the increasing interest in Shurima started, a sand Zac just seemed  to fit in. So I took the original art for Zac, and used it as an outline to create a Zac that looks like he is made of sand.

I personally think Zac could do very well with semi-amorphous armor like Xerath is composed of. Xerath has a clear intended shape, most visible near the end of his taunt emote; he's supposed to be a kind of sarcophagus, but the pieces of it are instead floating around in a humanoid form most of the time.

Zac could also work with this treatment; armored plates that are obviously designed for a particular shape, but able to float freely around each other without any rigid structure. The simplest reference I have for this idea is the PS4 character "Knack", whose body is composed of many tiny relics.

I've come up with a [Zac skin concept](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/skin-champion-concepts/zeU0ZpAv-nanobot-zac-scrap-heap-zac) based on having him made up of random pieces of metal rather than a liquid, if you'd be interested in checking it out.

Sand is much more than a recolor, many people think Zac's only skins can be recolors. But you can change the particles, and in soem cases additions like armor can be applied if applied correctly.

Not hard, just have the armor pop off of him when he does his stretch thing, then fall back into place.

If boots, just leave em untouched (leave them there) when he jumps out of them.

C'mon Rito, there are far easier, more creative solutions than thinking you require a stretchy material for everything.

You can also just make the sand fall away as he moves or uses abilities. 
Let's say he uses his q: instead of his hands retreating, after the punches are thrown, the sand just falls to the ground and his hands reform from the remaining sand of his body. 
For his w, just make the sand literally explode, and he reforms from the pile of sand left on the ground.
His e and ult would be a bit harder to do, because sand doesn't bounce so well, but it can be worked with.
